Expectation1: Represent clients in court hearings and trials
Situation1: A multi-day jury trial with significant damages at stake is set to commence shortly and cannot be delayed.
Expectation2: Attend weekly church services to worship and participate in community activities
Situation2: They recognize the importance of being present at weekly services regularly
Story: The courthouse buzzed with tension as I reviewed my notes for the trial set to begin tomorrow. My client’s future—and a substantial sum—rested on my ability to represent them without distraction. The judge had made it clear: no delays, no excuses. Every moment of preparation mattered. Yet, as I glanced at my calendar, my heart tightened. Sunday was the second day of trial, and I hadn’t missed a church service in years. My faith was my anchor, and worship with my community was more than a routine; it was a commitment I cherished deeply. I could already imagine the disappointment in my pastor’s eyes, the gentle questions from friends if I didn’t show up. The weight of my client’s trust pressed on one side, the pull of my faith on the other. I sat at my desk, torn, the expectations of both worlds colliding inside me, unsure which voice to heed.
